heading.title: PART 3 THE CIVIL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 25–161]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 3 THE CIVIL JURISDICTION OF THE COURT [ss 25–161]

p.text: The Court shall have jurisdiction to grant an injunction, to be called a temporary injunction, to restrain:
a threatened or apprehended trespass or nuisance, or
the breach of a negative stipulation in a contract the consideration for which does not exceed $20,000,
in like manner, subject to this Subdivision, as the Supreme Court might grant an interlocutory injunction in like circumstances.
[subs (1) am Act 169 of 1989 sÂ 3 and Sch 3]

Subject to this Subdivision, a temporary injunction shall continue in force for a specified period not exceeding fourteen days, but if the specified period is less than fourteen days, it may be renewed from time to time, but so that the total period for which the temporary injunction is in force does not exceed fourteen days.

A temporary injunction may be renewed so that the total period for which it is in force exceeds fourteen days if the Court is satisfied that the additional time is required to enable proceedings to be commenced or heard in the Supreme Court in relation to the matter.
A temporary injunction shall cease to be in force if:
the Court, on the application of a party, so orders, or
the Supreme Court, on the application of a party, so orders, whether or not the Supreme Court grants an injunction or gives any other relief in relation to the matter.
Proceedings for a temporary injunction may be commenced at any proclaimed place, not being a prescribed proclaimed place.
A temporary injunction may be renewed by the Court only where it is sitting at a proclaimed place that is not a prescribed proclaimed place.

A reference in this section to the renewal of a temporary injunction includes a reference to the grant of another temporary injunction in respect of the same matter by the Court, whether before or after the expiry of the firstmentioned injunction.

Lord Diplock pointed out in American Cyanamid Co v Ethicon Ltd [1975] AC 396 at 406; [1975] 1Â All ER 504Â the object of the grant of an interlocutory injunction is to protect the plaintiff against injury for which he or she could not be adequately compensated in damages if the alleged infringement of his or her rights by the defendant were to continue pending the resolution of the proceedings. However, the plaintiff's need for protection must be weighed against the defendant's corresponding need to be protected against injury resulting from being prevented from exercising the legal rights which he or she asserts but which are disputed by the plaintiff. Faced with this problem the court must in each case exercise its discretion in the manner best calculated to achieve justice between the parties: Appleton Papers Inc v Tomasetti Paper Pty Ltd [1983] 3Â NSWLR 208; (1983) 50 ALR 428Â ; Francome v Mirror Group Newspapers Ltd [1984] 2 All ER 408; [1984] 1Â WLR 892 at 894Â . In the exercise of that discretion not the least of the factors which the court must take into account are the nature and apparent strength of the plaintiff's case and the balance of convenience. Plainly enough, the strength of the plaintiff's case is a material factor and the court must be satisfied there is a real question to be tried: Eng Mee Yong v Letchumann [1980] AC 331 at 337Â ; American Cyanamid Co v Ethicon Ltd [1975] AC 396 at 407; [1975] 1Â All ER 504Â . The proposition that the plaintiff must go further and establish a prima facie case, while supported by authority: Beecham Group Ltd v Bristol Laboratories Pty Ltd (1968) 118 CLR 618 at 622; [1968] ALR 469; BC6800560Â ; Mirth Industries Ltd v Polyglass Engineering Pty Ltd (1975) 132 CLR 489; 6 ALR 212Â ; has been the subject of both debate and qualification. In Commonwealth v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1980) 147 CLR 39 at 49; 32 ALR 485; BC8000113Â MasonÂ J referred to the American Cyanamid test without disapproval and in Australian Coarse Grain Pool Pty Ltd v Barley Marketing Board of Queensland (No 1) (1982) 46 ALR 398; 57 ALJR 425Â Gibbs CJ preferred the American Cyanamid test to that in Beecham Group , above; see also Tableland Peanuts Pty Ltd v Peanut Marketing Board (1984) 52 ALR 651; 58 ALJR 283Â . Further, it is clear that in assessing the plaintiff's case the court is not required to attempt to conduct a preliminary trial and to give or withhold interlocutory relief according to some forecast of the likely final result of the proceedings: Beecham Group , above, at 622; Transport Workers' Union of Australia (NSW Branch) v Leon Laidely Pty Ltd (1980) 28 ALR 589 at 593; 43 FLR 168 at 170Â . It is sufficient if the plaintiff shows that he has a significant prospect of success: Michael Edgley International Pty Ltd v Ashtons Nominees Pty Ltd (1979) 26 ALR 419 at 421; 38 FLR 135 at 137Â ; Commercial Bank of Australia Ltd v Insurance Brokers Assn of Australia (1977) 16 ALR 161Â ; World Series Cricket Pty Ltd v Parish (1977) 16 ALR 181; (1977) ATPR Â¶40-040Â ; Victorian Egg Marketing Board v Parkwood Eggs Pty Ltd (1978) 20 ALR 129 at 145; 33 FLR 294 at 311Â . It would not seem, therefore, that while it is essential for the plaintiff to show the existence of a real question to be tried, in any particular case the degree of likelihood of success required to be shown, if any, is merely that which the court thinks sufficient to warrant preservation of the status quo in order to do justice between the parties: Shercliff v Engadine Acceptance Corp Pty Ltd [1978] 1Â NSWLR 729; Magna Alloys & Research Pty Ltd v Coffey [1981] VR 23Â ; Appleton Papers Inc v Tomasetti Paper Pty Ltd [1983] 3Â NSWLR 208; (1983) 50 ALR 428Â ; Construction Engineering (Aust) Pty Ltd v Tambel (A'asia) Pty Ltd [1984] 1Â NSWLR 274; De Mestre v AD Hunter Pty Ltd (1952) 77 WN (NSW) 143Â ; R Meagher, D Heydon and M Leeming Meagher, Gummow and Lehane’s, Equity Doctrines and Remedies, 4th ed, LexisNexis Butterworths, Sydney, 2002, at Ch 21. That, after all, is the ultimate purpose of the power to grant interlocutory relief and its exercise ought not be unduly restricted by rigid judicial formulae: Stollznow v Calvert [1980] 2Â NSWLR 749; Francome v Mirror Group Newspapers Ltd [1984] 2 All ER 408; [1984] 1Â WLR 892 at 894Â ; Appleton Papers , above.

The form of an order for injunction whether prohibitory or mandatory should be such as to show distinctly what is and what is not prohibited. For example, in Cother v Midland Railway Co (1848) 17 LJ Ch 235Â the defendant was entitled to enter upon the plaintiff's land for the necessary purposes of the railway. It was held that an injunction seeking to restrain the defendant from entering upon the land otherwise than for those purposes was improper as it did not determine the real question in issue between the parties: Warden of Dover Harbour v London Chatham & Dover Railway Co (1861) 30 LJ Ch 474 at 479; Attorney-General v Staffordshire County Council [1905] 1Â Ch 336 at 342 and Morris v Redland Bricks Ltd [1970] AC 652 at 666–7; [1969] 2Â All ER 576Â .
Legislation cited in [DCA s 140.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
Â
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 PtÂ 25, rrÂ 25.10, 25.17.
The District Court has jurisdiction to grant Mareva orders: see [DCA sÂ 46.10 ] and UCPRÂ PtÂ 25 especially rrÂ 25.10 – 25.17 .

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 140.20] Omission or concealment of material facts

heading.title: Omission or concealment of material facts

p.text: As a general rule lack of candour or omission to bring material facts to the attention of the court on an application for interlocutory injunction will lead to dissolution of any injunction obtained: Brown v Newall (1837) 2Â My & Cr 558; 40 ER 752; Thomas A Edison Ltd v Bullock (1912) 15 CLR 679; [1912] HCA 72Â ; Grant Matich & Co Pty Ltd v Toyo Menka Kaisha Ltd (1978) 3Â ACLR 375; Trewenack v Clipper's Anchorage Pty Ltd (SC(NSW), PowellÂ J in Eq, NoÂ 4446/1983, 8Â December 1983, unreported), Ritchie's Supreme Court Procedure [13,030]. Even if the material fact has been merely forgotten without malice, the rule still applies: Clifton v Robinson (1853) 16 Beav 355; 51 ER 816Â . But a non-disclosure will not be material unless it is likely to influence the Court in acceding to the application: South Downs Packers Pty Ltd v Beaver (1984) 8Â ACLR 990 at 1002. See also R v Kensington Income Tax Cmrs [1917] 1 KB 486Â ; Bentley v Nelson [1963] WAR 89Â ; Gilfillan v Gilfillan (1973) 6 SASR 330Â and Kerr on Injunctions, 6th ed pp 660–1. If the temporary injunction has expired, a lack of candour in relation to the original application is not directly relevant when considering an application for a further restraint: Bennett v Excelsior Land, Investment and Building Co Ltd (1893) 14 LR (NSW) Eq 179 at 182. Because of this, in South Downs Packers Pty Ltd v Beaver (1984) 8Â ACLR 990, some members of the Full Court of Queensland considered that the modern rule was not as strict or inflexible as stated in some of the older authorities. If an ex parte injunction is dissolved on the ground of concealment, the plaintiff is not precluded from making another application: Fitch v Rochfort (1849) 18 LJ Ch 458Â ; Thomas A Edison Ltd v Bullock (1912) 15 CLR 679 at 683; [1912] HCA 72Â ; Bennett v Excelsior Land, Investment and Building Co Ltd (1893) 14 LR (NSW) Eq 179 at 182.

As to “proclaimed place” see ss 4 and 18F DCA. Sydney is a proclaimed place. The “proclaimed places” prescribed for the purposes of s 140(5) & (6) are Campbelltown, Gosford, Liverpool and Penrith: DCR Pt 52 r 12.

The usual undertaking as to damages is provided for in r 25.8 UCPR. The giving of such an undertaking is the ordinary price which the plaintiff must be prepared to pay in order to obtain interim relief: Smith v Day (1882) 21 Ch D 421Â ; Air Express Ltd v Ansett Transport Industries (Operations) Pty Ltd (1981) 146 CLR 249; 33 ALR 578; BC8100053Â ; Australian Marketing Development Pty Ltd v Australian Interstate Marketing Pty Ltd [1972] VR 219 at 229Â ; Chisholm v Rieff (1953) 2 FLR 211Â . The court cannot compel the giving of an undertaking but it may refuse the application for interlocutory relief unless the undertaking is offered: Tucker v New Brunswick Trading Co of London (1890) 44 Ch D 249Â ; Kerridge v Foley [1968] 1 NSWR 628; (1968) 88 WN (NSW) 63Â . Even the Crown may be required to provide an undertaking as to damages — at least when it is suing to protect its proprietary rights: Commonwealth v John Fairfax & Sons Ltd (1980) 147 CLR 39; 32 ALR 485; BC8000113Â ; Secretary of State for Trade and Industry v Hoffmann-La-Roche & Co AG [1975] AC 295; [1973] 3 All ER 945Â . Where the party offering the undertaking is not within the jurisdiction it may be appropriate to require the undertaking to be provided by some responsible person who is within the jurisdiction: Spanish General Agency Corp v Spanish Corp (1890) 63 LTR (NS) 161 at 162, Myring v Beale (1899) 15 WN (NSW) 243 at 244; Chisholm v Rieff (1953) 2 FLR 211 at 214Â ; Cooper v Smyth (1883) 4 LR (NSW) Eq 39Â . However, the matter is one involving the exercise of discretion and where an order for the payment of damages pursuant to the undertaking could be readily enforced in the plaintiff's home jurisdiction it may be unnecessary to require a further undertaking: see for example, Connop v Varena Pty Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 71Â .

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 140.35] Undertaking in lieu of injunction

p.text: In lieu of considering whether an interlocutory or final injunction should be granted, the court may accept an undertaking from a party. Undertakings are of two types: undertakings inter parties which have the force of a mere agreement between the parties; and undertakings to the court which can be enforced in the same way as for breach of an injunction: Biba Ltd v Stratford Investments Ltd [1973] Ch 281 at 287; [1972] 3 All ER 1041Â . However, it is a mistake to equate injunctions and undertakings, as in some respect they are different, see, for example, Spindler v Balog (1959) 76 WN (NSW) 391Â (undertaking to pay money) and see Cutler v Wandsworth Stadium Ltd [1945] 1 All ER 103Â .

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 140.40] Variation of injunction or undertaking

p.text: It is clear that the court has complete power to vary interlocutory injunctions or orders to take account of changed circumstances: Mullins v Howell (1879) 11 Ch D 763 at 766Â ; Wilkshire v Commonwealth (1976) 9 ALR 325 at 366Â ; Philip Morris Inc v Adam P Brown Male Fashions Pty Ltd (1980) 148 CLR 457; 31 ALR 232 at 253. The court also undoubtedly has power, even in the absence of consent, to release a party from an interlocutory undertaking. However, it should be borne in mind that an undertaking given by a party may have a contractual aspect where it is given in order to induce a plaintiff not to pursue an application for an interlocutory injunction. Release of such an undertaking by the court does not affect the liability of the party to pay damages for breach of contract: Cutler v Wandsworth Stadium Ltd [1945] 1 All ER 103Â ; Chanel Ltd v FW Woolworth & Co Ltd [1981] 1 All ER 745; [1981] 1 WLR 485Â ; Adam P Brown Male Fashions Pty Ltd v Philip Morris Inc (1981) 148 CLR 170 at 177–8; 35 ALR 625 at 629–30Â and see Purcell v FC Trigell Ltd [1971] 1 QB 358; [1970] 3 All ER 671Â .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 141] s 141 Powers of Court under this Subdivision

leg:heading.title: Powers of Court under this Subdivision

p.text: With respect to temporary injunctions—

the Court and the Judges shall, in addition to the powers and authority otherwise conferred on it and them, have all the powers and authority of the Supreme Court and the Judges thereof with respect to the granting of interlocutory injunctions;
the appropriate officer of the Court shall, in addition to the duties otherwise imposed on the officer, discharge—
any duty which an officer of the Supreme Court would be required under the practice of the Supreme Court to discharge with respect to interlocutory injunctions; and
any duty imposed on the officer by the rules or by any order of the Court;

the practice and procedure of the Court shall, so far as practicable and subject to this Act and the rules, be the same as the practice and procedure of the Supreme Court applicable with respect to the granting of interlocutory injunctions; and

without affecting the generality of the foregoing provisions of this section, the powers, authority and duty conferred by paragraphs (a) and (b) , and the practice and procedure of the Court referred to in paragraph (c) , shall, subject to the rules, extend to the enforcement of a temporary injunction and any order of the Court made in connection with proceedings for the granting of the temporary injunction.
[sÂ 141 am Act 32 of 1994 sÂ 3 and Sch 3]
Without affecting the generality of any other provision of this Act authorising the making of rules, the rules may make provision for or with respect to—
the procedure to be followed with respect to the granting and enforcing of temporary injunctions;
the costs of proceedings in the Court in relation to temporary injunctions; and
any other matter necessary or convenient for giving effect to this Subdivision.
This section does not give power to make rules with respect to any matter relating to costs that is regulated by Part 3.2 of the Legal Profession Act 2004.
[subs (2) insrt Act 87 of 1993 s 4 and Sch 6; am Act 58 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3.4[4], effective 20 June 2006]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 142.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

(NSW) District Court Rules 1973 Pt 52 r 12.
Apart from the provisions of DCR Pt 52 r 12 , no other rules have been made.
